data.title: Foreword
data.description:
I have, with God's help, already survived two years and have now begun to think how to get through the third year and the eight months that were left and how to get out of Fonie’s* hands and become a free man as before. But man should not think ahead because according to an old Jewish proverb - man plans and God laughs.

Suddenly a new situation arises: we must go to fight a war in Manchuria, which is in China and be cast away hundreds of miles from home. And we must go there to fight the enemy - as if he took something away from me. Nevertheless. I hope that I will overcome everything and return safely, unharmed. And may it be for the best. Amen.

Now I will describe our departure from Zhmerinke and everything that happened until our arrival at that desolate place, Manchuria. Riflemen were needed in Manchuria and as I served in the 9th Riflemen Brigade I too had to go there. God knows how long this war will last and whether we will ever return. I decided to keep a diary and that I would write down everything that will happen with me until the last day of my life.

If it is ordained that I should return, then 1 will be able to recall everything, and if not - God forbid- if I should have to give my life for King and country, then this diary will serve as an everlasting memorial for me. And I ask my good comrades who will be there with me that they hand this diary over to my parents.

May God grant that I be worthy to return to my homeland. Then I will gather all my good friends and recount from beginning to end the journey to China.

*Fonie=Yiddish slang for Russian or The Russians.

data.title: Mezhibezh to Zhmerinke
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Zhmerinka / Zhmerynka, Жмеринка / Жмеринка

The 26th of June.

As we were returning from camp in Mezhibezh. we didn't know a thing yet. Along the way we were greeted by a telegram from the Minister of War ordering our brigade to get to Manchuria as quickly as possible. This news did not make us happy at all and with our heads down we continued on our way to Zhmerinke.

Then started a wailing and weeping - the wives of the officers were crying: one fainted, another overcome by her troubles was lying on her bed half- dead, knowing that her husband has to go to war. Now the soldiers were making a tummult* and a clamor.

One wrote a letter. another a postcard. And another tried to send a telegram to parents, to a brother, a sister, uncle, aunts or to in-laws - asking that they should come to say good- bye because we are leaving for such a long journey and God only knows whether we will return alive - and requesting also that the relatives bring some money for the journey.

We ran to the post office to mail our letters and our telegrams, but they took them and tore them up; we should not make such a tumult about the war. We then submitted a petition to the chief of military operations: isn't it bad enough that we are leaving for such a long journey? Shouldn't we, at least, be allowed to notify our parents of our whereabouts? A telegram came back immediately saying that it is not forbidden to write about these things and that we may write whatever we want.

Notes:

*tummult = confusion, often noisy

data.title: Zhmerinke:  "...in the Czar's army you had to suffer."
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Zhmerinka / Zhmerynka, Жмеринка / Жмеринка

The next day- what a horror! Heaven help us!

O God, my God! How terrible it was for the people who received a telegram informing them that their son or brother is going to war. They came broken-hearted to say good- bye. Some men had only three months of military service left and were getting ready to go home - in the end they had to go to war.

Here is a scene.

Parents are kissing and embracing their son and crying: "Oh my dear, we waited and lived for the day when you will have finished your service and you would come home and help us earn our living and now you have to go off to war. Oh dear son, my only kadish woe is me."*

The son tries to console them: "Never mind, God will help and I will return as soon as possible."

Now they take out the few rubles which they brought with them and give it to him and say: "Here, dear son, take it, you will have something to keep body and soul together on this long trip, don't worry and please, write often and let us know how it goes with you. Do not forget God and he will deliver you from all danger."

They kiss and embrace him and shed many tears and take leave of him. This scene is enough to move a stone to tears.

Then comes a young woman, carrying a child in one arm and leading the other by the hand and shouting: "I waited for you three years, I waited for you like one waits for the messiah." lt seems that she lived all this time with his parents, the "dear" father-in-law and mother-in-law. She complains "they are annoying me and are making my life miserable and now you are going off to war!" And she is clamoring that he should give her conditional divorce papers.

Can you just imagine this scene. He is happy to see his children and his wife and says to her "Don't make so much noise; God will help and I will return." He doesn't want to part so abruptly from his wife and he kisses the children, then husband and wife kiss and so they part and shed many tears. lt is awful to watch.

Suddenly a future father-in-law comes looking for his prospective son-in-law, who signed a betrothal agreement with his daughter last winter while on furlough. Now he is asking the young man to give back the betrothal agreement because who knows how long his daughter will have to wait for him to return- or whether he will ever return at all.

These scenes are repeated many times over among our soldiers.

In the middle of all this commotion arrived our battalion commander and announced: "Fellows, see to it that you sell or send home all your belongings. You will be allowed to take with you only 2 shirts, 2 pairs of long johns, 2 towels and nothing else."

This caused a new commotion: how to go and sell your few meager Fonie army belongings. But what could we poor soldiers do? We had to sell what we could. There were soldiers who would have completed their military service in another two months. Whichever one among them could afford it, had ordered for himself in anticipation of his release from the army, a suit of civilian clothes. Some struggled hard to be able to pay for it. And now they had to sell their miserable belongings for half price. lt was certainly a pity but, in the Czar's army you had to suffer. And so - each one of us put his meager belongings under his arm and walked to town.

ln the small town of Zhrnerinke there was a clean, open market square where Jews and non-Jews did their buying and selling and bartering. But this military business was a lucky thing for the local Jews. A whole new world opened up for them! lmagine! There were four thousand soldiers and each one needed to sell his belongings.

Many buyers came from the surrounding towns and villages and carried away wagons full of soldiers' belongings which they bought at half the usual price. lt was a big thing for the local Jews - for the soldiers it was misery. You think to yourself and say: the devil take the belongings, the worn boots and clothing and the Zhmerinke Jews as well.

lf God will help us and we will survive and return unharmed - even if it be without

the shirt we're taking along - we will thank Him for this favor. And even if we bring back the shirt and the long johns, we will have to return them to the army anyway.

data.title: Zhmerinke: "The officer bears his burden."
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Zhmerinka / Zhmerynka, Жмеринка / Жмеринка

The officer bears his burden - he has to sell his bit of property: a bed, a table, a samovar, (4) worn trousers, and Russian army boots. What does he do? He calls a soldier and tells him to sell his bundle of things. What should the soldier do? He hasn't sold his own things yet and now he has to sell someone else’s? The soldier figures: never mind, the hell with it! We will straighten out the account later. So he sells the officers things but keeps half of the money: fifty-fifty, half for you - half for me. The officer pockets the meager amount because if he had to do it himself. He wouldn't have gotten even that much.

Soldiers are busy doing all kinds of things, but Jewish soldiers don't like to work, particularly now, when they have all kinds of worries on their mind. And if you don't believe me - come and visit the Jewish soldiers of the 9th Regiment and see for yourself: one is drinking tea, one is eating a roll with a piece of meat another is sitting with his head down, overcome by his troubles - thinking how to give Fonie the slip and leave for America. One soldier is telling another that his father served in the army of Czar Nicholas 1 and fought in the Turkish War (probably the Crimean War) We listen to his tales and we are terrified of the war more even than of the Angel of Death.

In another corner two Jews are sitting and figuring. I am sure you would like to guess what it is they are trying to figure out. No, you won't guess. Two days later we found out that they were thinking of going to London. One of them was figuring that the borders are closed tight because of the war and if they should be caught they would be executed. So he figured: no, in that case I'd rather go to China and if it is so ordained then I will return from there.

You will find a second or third and a fourth - all with similar thoughts in their heads. The end result was that they vanished.

The gentiles are laughing and saying: "The Jew is afraid of war” and similar things. Many Jews fled from those regiments.

data.title: Zhmerinke: The General's Speech
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Zhmerinka / Zhmerynka, Жмеринка / Жмеринка

On July 6 a general arrived from Kiev. He was sent by the supreme military commander to say good-bye to us.

At 10 AM, the bugle sounded assembly. We put on full battle gear and fell into formation at the parade grounds (mustering square). First the regiment commander then the general greeted us: "Listen fellows, as you are standing here facing your flag, I want to say a few words to you." We are standing and trembling and are eager to hear what he has to say. "Brothers, see to it that you give a good account of yourselves and excel as your brothers before you did, who fought the enemy till the last drop of their blood for the fatherland and for the Czar."

He also told us that the 9th Regiment is respected in all of Russia, showed themselves to be brave in battle in the past and is very famous. At that we shouted, "Hurrah! Hurrah!" so loud that it could be heard at quite a distance from here. He bade us farewell and wished us bon voyage.

At that moment a terrible fear came upon us all and tears were flowing like water from the officers as well as the soldier's eyes. When the shout "Hurrah! Hurrah!" went up, the general bowed to us and then to the officers and shook hands with each of them. Then he walked up to the flag bearer, kissed the flag and said to him: "Remember, don't let this flag out of your hands till the last drop of blood in your veins." Then we were dismissed and the general left.

data.title: Zhmerinke: "We worked all day"
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Zhmerinka / Zhmerynka, Жмеринка / Жмеринка

We worked all day carrying the army gear, which was needed for the journey, to the railroad depot. At 11 A.M. we ate our meal and before we could even finish eating the bugle sounded assembly. We threw down the mess kits with the kasha* and the borscht and ran to put on full battle gear, and then we fell into formation. We looked at our barracks, which appeared now, empty and deserted. A feeling of terror came upon us.

Many people were gathered in the parade grounds. Jews, Christians. Civilians and military people - all came to say good-bye and to observe the departure ceremony.

Then came the regiment commander with the brigade General Katrievitch. The general greeted us first, then came the military chaplain. He conducted a prayer service: he offered a prayer for the welfare of the Czar and his heir and then wished us success and good luck on our journey.

The rabbi came to see us, the Jewish soldiers. He brought with him a scroll of the Torah** and asked the general if he could conduct a service for us. Permission was granted. The rabbi stood near a table, put on a talis*** and recited a few psalms. (honoten y'shuo. a misheberach****) and that was the end our service. Then Schwartzman, the contractor, brought wine and said he wanted to drink to the general's health. And the general gave permission.

Four silver goblets were brought and filled with wine. The first goblet was given to the general. The second - to our regiment commander. The third - to the commander of the 10th regiment and the fourth - to Schwartsman. The general drank to the health of His Imperial Majesty, the Czar and to the health of Her Imperial Majesty, the Czarina; then he drank to the health of the inhabitants of the town of Zhmerinke, which he said gave him so much joy. We yelled: "Hurrah! Hurrah!” the band played and they all drank the first toast. Then Schwartzman drank to the health of their Excellencies. The commanders of the 9th and the 10th regiments and to the health of all the riflemen and we yelled: "Hurrah! Hurrah"'

Then came the regiment commander with the brigade General Katrievitch. The general greeted us first, then came the military chaplain. He conducted a prayer service: he offered a prayer for the welfare of the Czar and his heir and then wished us success and good luck on our journey.

The rabbi came to see us, the Jewish soldiers. He brought with him a scroll of the Torah** and asked the general if he could conduct a service for us. Permission was granted. The rabbi stood near a table, put on a talis*** and recited a few psalms. (honoten y'shuo. a misheberach****) and that was the end our service. Then Schwartzman, the contractor, brought wine and said he wanted to drink to the general's health. And the general gave permission.

Four silver goblets were brought and filled with wine. The first goblet was given to the general. The second - to our regiment commander. The third - to the commander of the 10th regiment and the fourth - to Schwartsman. The general drank to the health of His Imperial Majesty, the Czar and to the health of Her Imperial Majesty, the Czarina; then he drank to the health of the inhabitants of the town of Zhmerinke, which he said gave him so much joy. We yelled: "Hurrah! Hurrah!” the band played and they all drank the first toast. Then Schwartzman drank to the health of their Excellencies. The commanders of the 9th and the 10th regiments and to the health of all the riflemen and we yelled: "Hurrah! Hurrah"'

As we arrived at the railroad station - it was packed full of people. Parents, brothers, sisters and friends were wailing - all wanted to say good-bye and to wish us a pleasant journey. The screaming and the hollering is loud enough to reach the heavens. Just then we heard the first bell. The officers were shouting "into the (train) cars!" The good-byes were said, the tears were pouring and the reminders were heard: “For God's sake, don't forget to write letters!” We got into the cars - twenty soldiers to a car and as we sat down in our seats we heard the second and third bells.

The band was playing a march and all the people were waving good- bye with their hats or with their kerchiefs. The photographer took another picture. The engineer blew the whistle and the train started moving. Feeling sad and brokenhearted the soldiers began singing Russian songs. The singing was worse (sadder) than the crying. Some people were still waving good- bye but the train started moving and it was difficult to see now. We could still hear shouts of “Farewell! Farewell!" Some soldiers were crying and the tears were flowing like water when they heard the shouts of farewell and each one thought to himself: "Who knows whether we will ever see each other again, whether we will ever return and see Zhmerinke."

We soldiers were sitting in our train cars like chickens before the slaughter. Meanwhile, the train stopped at the railroad station at Vinitse. We were received nicely. The local band was playing and the sign was given to get out of the train cars and then we just stood around for twenty minutes. Many people came running, Jews and Gentiles, and everybody was asking: "Where are you going?" We told everybody in secret: "We are off to war." One person sighed upon hearing this. Another groaned, a third rolled his eyes and got weepy. We were already sick and tired of the public's reaction to our going to war. The first bell rang, the signal was given to get back into the train cars, our "horse" gave a whistle and the train was moving off. All the people were bowing to us taking off their hats and we were yelling: "Hurrah! Hurrah!" The shouting almost broke the train car apart.

Now night was falling. We started looking around for a place to sleep. But woe! There was nothing to sleep on but the slatted coach seats and even these would not accommodate everybody. Just imagine! Twenty men to a car and there was nothing to put under you for bedding. What was a soldier to do? He had a soldier's coat, a "shinel"* - that's all. As he lay down to sleep the soldier put his shinel under him. And he also covered himself with his shinel and put it under his head as well. So, it would seem that the soldier slept well! When we got up in the morning there was not a bone in our bodies that didn't ache because of these "soft" beds that we were sleeping in. When we considered how long we will have to keep on rolling around on these "soft" beds and continue going through all kinds of hardships - it made us feel even worse.

data.title: Kursk
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Kursk (Vorozba) Курск

At 10 o'clock in the morning we arrived in KURSK. Kursk is a very big city. The train was delayed and we just waited for two hours. As we got out of our train cars a group of soldiers came up to us. We asked them whether there was any news. They said that everything was quiet around here and they hadn't heard any news.

We were given permission to go into the city. Kursk is a very big city but very few Jews were to be found here.

As we got into the city in the dark of night, a whole bright world opened up before us. We went shopping for food and we did really well: we bought rolls, bread, sugar tea, salami, cigarette paper and things like that which a soldier needs. However. One soldier paid for his purchase and five did not. The merchants made a profit anyway. They knew that we were going to war and they probably figured:" Let them go!" They also knew that we were the first brigades coming and they will do a lot more business.

At 10 o'clock at night we left Kursk. A big crowd came to see us off at the railroad station and everybody was curious to find out where we were going. The band played as we got into our train cars. The third bell rang, the locomotive gave a whistle and we were moving away. The people were bowing to us and we were singing songs and shouting: "Hurrah! Hurrah!"

An unusual thing happened as we were leaving Kursk. Several soldiers were left behind because they got drunk - dead drunk - and we didn't know where to find them.

On July 14th we arrived in a big city called PENDZE. A lot of people gathered around when we arrived. We went to eat dinner.

My reply to him was: "You came with nothing - you'll leave with nothing. And I thought to myself: "Why don't you give me five kopecks and then I will pray for you- which you leave me alone and get lost." We didn't think much of this alms-giving business.

They were poor and looked threadbare and it was a pity to look at them. They were traveling at government expense just like soldiers: fifty people in one freight car, including women and children. They were receiving (from the government) half a pound of meat and a pound of bread for a mere three kopecks and borscht and tea for free.

data.title: Crossing the Volga to Samar
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Samara, Сама́ра

On July 15th we crossed over a very long bridge which spanned the Volga River.

At noon we arrived in Samar - also a very big day. We had our meal near the railroad station and then each one of us received two glasses of beer. We didn't know where this beer came from or who had donated it, Later we learned that there was a wealthy brewer here in Samar and that he treated the entire brigade to free beer because we were going to war. That was very nice and I wouldn't have minded having some beer every day - and some food as well.

After we had the beer we went into the city. The city of Samar is very big but very few Jews could be found here. Those who lived here were all tradesmen who received residence-permits because deep inside Russia (outside the pale of settlement) Jews were not allowed to live unless they received special permission. And when you met one of these Jews, you would never recognize that it was a Jew because they had become thoroughly crucified, spoke only Russian and knew very little of their Jewish heritage.

We left Samar as the band was playing merrily.

We didn't know where this beer came from or who had donated it, Later we learned that there was a wealthy brewer here in Samar and that he treated the entire brigade to free beer because we were going to war. That was very nice and I wouldn't have minded having some beer every day - and some food as well.

After we had the beer we went into the city. The city of Samar is very big but very few Jews could be found here. Those who lived here were all tradesmen who received residence-permits because deep inside Russia (outside the pale of settlement) Jews were not allowed to live unless they received special permission. And when you met one of these Jews, you would never recognize that it was a Jew because they had become thoroughly crucified, spoke only Russian and knew very little of their Jewish heritage.

We left Samar as the band was playing merrily.

On July 18th we stopped at a station in Ofimsk region.

This region is populated mainly by Tartars. Many of them were waiting at the railroad station in order to see their sons who were serving in our brigade. As we got off the train a weeping and wailing started among them of a kind which we have never encountered before. They were happy to see their sons and they were kissing each other, but you could not find a woman among them even with a flashlight. According to their custom a woman is not supposed to show her face (to a man) until she is eighteen years old. You find here also Kirgiz people - This is also one of the nations around here.

data.title: Omsk
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Omsk, Омск

On July 23rd we arrived in Omsk in the Malinovsky region.

As we were approaching the railroad station a miracle occurred: We had to cross over a long bridge a couple of miles before we got to the railroad station. Some Kirgiz men wanted to blow up the bridge just as our train was moving across it. They placed dynamite charges under the railroad ties. Had this dynamite exploded we would have perished - they would not have been able to find even a shred of our remnants. However, this business was discovered in time and these men were caught and sent away (where they deserved to be) in chains. An order was issued immediately that a man should be placed every couple of miles to guard the railroad and that soldiers should guard every bridge.

Omsk is a very big city in Siberia and people could be found here from all over Russia and Poland - but all were exiles. Nevertheless. They were doing rather well here. They were wealthy and were doing big business.

Here in Omsk we celebrated a regimental holiday. We fell in formation and our general came with the chaplain who conducted a prayer service. As we stood there a photographer came and took a picture of the whole regiment. We had some vodka and ate dinner.

We went into the city and found many Jews who were living here but came from Warsaw. They were exiled to Omsk and had been living here a long time. Many soldiers who came from Warsaw themselves found relatives here who they had never heard of before: uncles, aunts, brothers-in-law and also close friends. They received the soldiers with respect and gave them food and money. What a pity that no relative of mine could be found here who would give me some money - but what could I do? There was none.

A couple of hours later we were on our way.

data.title: Stretinsk Harbour
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Sretinsk

On August 10th we arrived at Stretinsk in the CHABAROVSK region. This is where the Siberian railroad ended.

Until now we were in pretty good spirits. We traveled on dry land and with the shouts of "Hurrah! Hurrah!" and the singing of songs we traveled across European Russia and much of Siberia. Now begins Asia. It reeks already of China and Manchuria.

Stratinsk is a harbor and a Cossack dty. Here live mainly Cossacks. You can find Jews too but very few in number.

We got off the train and took all our belongings out of the train car and all the regimental baggage as well. We said good-bye to the train cars that carried us such a long way.

We remained at Stretinsk harbor for half a day. We needed to continue our journey by railroad but the Chinese damaged the railroad tracks so that the Russians wouldn't be able to bring any reinforcements to the battle area. For that reason we had to stay here. We sent a telegram asking for instructions on how we should proceed and what we should do. We were instructed to continue our journey on water. The waterway here was the river Shilka (or Shilke).

We needed to get to Blagovieshtghensk. We took on provisions for twenty days and boarded a ship and took four freight barges along too. Here we could see already the Chinese because of whom we covered all this distance - just to have a look at them (ha! ha!).

They are dark-skinned people who wear braids - whether man or woman, they all wear braids.

There are plenty of wealthy Chinese here. When the war started they converted to the Russian Orthodox faith and they were doing real well in their businesses.

The dress of the Chinese is old-fashioned. They don't wear shirts and long johns (underwear) but they wear two pairs of trousers. One pair is long and the other, a short pair is worn over the long pair. It looks like a shield or some kind of armor. The sleeves are short. They all smoke long pipes - young and old. You don't see any women among them because they are afraid to show their face.

data.title: Blagovieshtchensk
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Blagovieshtchensk, Благовещенск

On August 20th, with God's help, we arrived in BLAGOVIESHTCHENSK.

We disembarked and fell into formation at the harbor. The governor general arrived and congratulated us upon our arrival in the Amur region. We thanked him and he in turn praised us for having arrived from Russia and for having covered such a great distance. Afterward they took us around and quartered us in private homes. Blagovieshtchensk is a big city and it is located near the water (near a river). On the opposite shore is located a Chinese city called Sachalin. A few days ago the Chinese started an uprising. They captured a Russian man and did some terrible things to him. They didn't kill him right away but they tortured him; they cut off his ear and his hand or his leg. Later that day they killed him. They beheaded him and then put a stick in the torso and carried it around the city. Because of that incident the war started and the Chinese began shooting at Blagovieshtchensk.

Here in Blagovieshtchensk were stationed reservists who responded to the Chinese attack and the war began. They laid siege to the Chinese city until they captured it and burned it down. Many Chinese were killed but some managed to flee for their lives. Here in Blagovieshtchensk too lived many Chinese, about 4000. Some of them fled and the rest were rounded up and tied together by their braids then they were led to the water (river) and told to go across. Those who managed to get across - good and well; those who didn't remained in the water and were left to learn how to swim - forever.

What did the Chinese do? Many converted to the Russian Orthodox faith but some drowned themselves and left all their possessions. The local soldiers gathered in plenty of wealth. They treat money like trash. Then what is the problem? Their lives hang by a thread. We still see many Chinese who barely survived the drowning who come back and want to beat up the soldiers who stole their possessions.

We are being billeted (housed) in elegant Chinese living rooms that have no window panes because they have been shot out by cannon fire.

We are living it up! Mainly we are resting up from the long, tiring trip. We are fixing up our equipment and we even have to resole our boots because we are expecting trouble ahead. We were commanded to get everything in order. The problem is that everything is expensive here: a pair of leather soles cost 80 kopecks. The boots have to be fixed because we expect an inspection.

Food is not very expensive here. You can eat fish instead of bread because bread is more expensive than fish. After a stay of a few days an order arrived that we should do "volunteer work."

The Chinese city that was captured and now belongs to the Russians is called Elinsk Post. There are many fields of ripe produce which must be harvested: rye and wheat and many other things. We have been commanded to cut the grain.

Meanwhile, a general arrived from St. Petersburg and ordered a dress parade to check whether we have everything that we will need on our further travels. We were ordered to travel 7200 Viorst (13) to Charbin.

Meanwhile, we are sitting here and resting our weary bones. We march into the center of town every day singing Russian songs. The local residents are happy to see us because we are Russian soldiers from Russia and that seems to be very important to them.

They captured a Russian man and did some terrible things to him. They didn't kill him right away but they tortured him; they cut off his ear and his hand or his leg. Later that day they killed him. They beheaded him and then put a stick in the torso and carried it around the city.    Because of that incident the war started and the Chinese began shooting at Blagovieshtchensk.

Here in Blagovieshtchensk were stationed reservists who responded to the Chinese attack and the war began. They laid siege to the Chinese city until they captured it and burned it down. Many Chinese were killed but some managed to flee for their lives. Here in Blagovieshtchensk too lived many Chinese, about 4000. Some of them fled and the rest were rounded up and tied together by their braids then they were led to the water (river) and told to go across. data.title: Leaving Blagovieschtchensk on the Amur River
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Amur River

On September 2nd we took on provisions for the journey and we got ready for another inspection. Then came the governor lieutenant- General Gribsky. He praised us, said his goodbyes and wished us a successful journey. Now we don't stop to cook our food at the shore any more. They built ovens on the barges and the food is cooked right there. We are tired of eating hard tack, it feels like our teeth are being ground down. All through this trip we got no fresh meat, but we are getting canned meat. In this way we travel days and nights. All we can see are tall mountains and from time to time we pass a Chinese village. These villages have been burned to the ground. You don't see any people - not even a dog can be seen. We are now sailing in Chinese waters.

That is how we continued until 19th Sept. We saw many ships with cargoes of all sorts going from Charbin to Blagovieshtchensk. We arrived in Charbin at 4 o'clock in the afternoon. data.title: Leaving Charbin on Yom Kippur
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Charbin

Early the next day we left Charbin with broken hearts. How can they do this to us? We are going to battle on Yom Kippur? Each Jewish soldier walks around with a broken heart, recites psalms or other Jewish prayers - each according to his ability and each petition the Dear God that He should inscribe us in the Book of Life*. We ask God that he should save us from the sword and all evil because we are now in real trouble. We recite the confession several times during the day, weeping- m case some of us may no longer be able to recite.

We davened** N'ilah*** and we recited “and seal us in the Book of Life" with all our hearts. Then we prayed the evening service, we broke fast and we assured each other our Dear God heard our petition and that He will help us in our need, and we assured ourselves that our prayers have been accepted for a good New Year.

Notes:

*"...petition the Dear God that He should inscribe us in the Book of Life," ie bless them with a safe and fruitful year to come.

**davened, prayed

***N'ilah, the final service for Yom Kippur

data.title: Sailing and Marching to Banyasasa
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Bayangang

The 22nd September we traveled till 5 o'clock in the afternoon and we pulled over to the bank of the river. We were issued 30 bullets and now we each have 60. They gave us biscuits and canned rations for two days and we were told to be ready to march in the morning.

We slept through the night in fear - we thought: tomorrow we will fight the treacherous enemy, the Chinese, the source of our trouble. For the longest time we have had no rest - where we spent the day, we didn't sleep the night. We have to take revenge on the enemy - with God's help. These were the thoughts that were going through our minds.

At 4 o'clock in the morning our ship approached the opposite shore. We dressed in full battle gear and stood in formation with the artillery and the Cossacks. During the night the Regiment Commander arrived and now they were shouting orders: Attention! On guard! He bade us farewell and said to us: "Now, men, you are going to capture a Chinese city. See to it that you fight to the last drop of blood! Don't let the enemy trample you - on the contrary - you should break the enemy and smash him, and see to it that you excel like your brethren excelled in all they did. But in case they should surrender, in case they willingly surrender the city, don't you dare to touch a thing! Do not rob or take anything because you will be held strictly accountable for this, just like many others who did these things and lost their lives.”

The regiment commander was riding with a Chinese man who was an interpreter. He can speak Russian and he also needs to translate everything which is said in Chinese. In this formation we marched 40 viorst* Two viorst before the city we stopped. We did not have to wait very long before the fataton arrived. A fataton is a Chinese governor. He spoke to our regiment commander and handed him the keys to the city and the keys to the fort and told him that he can now do as pleases.

data.title: Entering Bayansasa
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Bayangang

Our commander did not waste any time deliberating and ordered us to march into the city. The Chinese greeted us with great joy. Many fled when they heard that an army was approaching and for fear they hid in the forests. As we marched into the city we saw in every window a white flag which is a sign of peace and an indication that they don't want to fight.

All the Chinese from the oldest to the youngest lined the streets shouting: "Shanza!" They were pointing to their thumbs and were laughing. This is a Chinese sign indicating that we are good people.

We marched into the center of the city where the fort was located. We found no soldiers there but a lot of arms: swords, rifles, artillery pieces, a lot of dynamite and soldiers' uniforms. Everything was confiscated including some Chinese flags. We emptied the fort down to the bare walls, not even a pin was left. We searched the entire city - the more we searched, the more we found. We confiscated everything but Chinese soldiers were nowhere to be found. It began to pour and we had to spend the night here. We had no choice but to set up tents. They brought some straw and we got into the tents and went to sleep. The rain continued all night long. Every two hours the two-man patrol was changed so that we were guarded against an unexpected attack. But with God's help the night passed peacefully without fear.

data.title: "Well, we have now conquered one city and its chickens."
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Bayangang

Another day dawned, we continued our search for arms but there was nothing to be found any more.

Whenever we walk into a Chinese house we don't see any women - they were hiding together with their children. Sometimes we find a woman sitting in the living room - the poor thing sits alone in the room or in the basement and doesn't say a word, except when we come in she says: "shanza."

The search for arms is over. We are staying in the center of the city and the Chinese bring us jugs of chandza; this is a Chinese whiskey. For 5 kopecks you can get yourself drunk. But what we want is food to eat. What is to be done? The Chinese don't bake bread - you can't find any bread for love nor money. Because they don't bake bread they make flat cakes with oil and flour and they harden it over steam. It costs one kopeck a piece. But we want something to eat - we have had almost nothing to eat the last two days. Now to make the story short, we started looking for something to eat. As you walk into the courtyard of a Chinese house you see chickens. We didn't ask any questions, we didn't even take the chicken to the shochet* - we just twisted the chicken's head off, plucked off the feathers and cooked it. Some soldiers ran to the fields and dug up some potatoes and some com and we baked these on the fire.

Around 9 o'clock I look around - it looks like the preparation for a holiday feast. The soldiers make as much noise as a bunch of women preparing for the Sabbath. One is slicing something, another is slaughtering a chicken. A third one is peeling potatoes and some are just standing around and looking on.

We have many bonfires going because it is getting cold here. We are warming ourselves by the fires, we are boiling tea and drinking it without sugar - there is no sugar to be had because "life is sweet as sugar." Everyone is busy doing something so that there is no time to walk over to the Chinese and try to converse a little with them. They come over smoking their long pipes. Their black braids reach down to the knees. In addition to the beautiful hair they also have long fingernails.

They speak - we don't understand them and they don't understand us. They shout: "Ruski soldat shanza!" When one of our soldiers asks them: "Babushka**?" - The Chinese answers "Babushka dalyoko" i.e. the babushka is far away. When you ask a Chinese whether he has a wife or a sister he answers that she went away very far. Actually she is hiding in the cellar.

Now we are beginning to speak Chinese.

The city we are now staying in is called Banya Sasa. Two battalions of soldiers are to remain here as well as 100 Cossacks and the rest of us are to move on.

Well, we have now conquered one city and its chickens. This is a big city with a lot of factories. A telegram was dispatched to the Czar that we have conquered one city and that we have three more to conquer. A reply came back that we should proceed further.

Notes:

*shochet, i.e. to the kosher slaughterer

** babushka, ie woman

data.title: Marching to, and Taking Fen Dziah
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Fen Dziah

We left the city and marched 40 viorst (20) to the bank of the river. We embarked and traveled a few viorst by boat. We got off the boat and then marched two days on foot. We came to a city called Fen Dziah. The interpreter was sent ahead to inquire whether they will surrender peacefully or whether we will have to fight and bum down the city. They got scared and threw open all the gates of the city and gave us the keys to the city. We proceeded with the search for weapons as we did in the other city. All the weapons we could find were confiscated.

Here we carried on a battle with the chickens with eggs and with geese. We grabbed them by their tails - it was a fearful picture.

The final count was one chicken per soldier. We had a dinner - a real feast. We ate real well and then tried to converse with the Chinese in sign language. Whatever they bring to sell they ask for a ruble. What do our soldiers do? The soldiers take a kopeck and polish it till it sparkles white. They call it silver money. As long as it is white it is O.K. But not everybody can be fooled this way.

Notes:

data.title: Entering San Dzian
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: San Dzian

The 1st and 2nd battalions and 100 Cossacks remained in Fen Dziah. The remaining four battalions are moving on further. We stopped at a river bank. My battalion is to be stationed here. The town is called San Dzian. We entered the town - it was deserted, not even a dog was to be seen. When the Chinese heard that soldiers were coming they fled with their wives and children and left all their property unattended.

The elder of the town remained and he showed us the fort where Chinese soldiers had been stationed but they fled.

We entered the fort. We have to settle down here so we immediately started working like horses. Everything needed fixing. Chinese houses have no window panes and no ovens. They have empty rooms and holes in the walls and here winter is coming. We started fixing things up. We need a kitchen to cook food and an oven to bake bread and quarters with window panes. However, there are no window panes to be had. That is not the Chinese style. We had to make windows their style that is paper smeared with oil. We worked eight hours a day. Everything was fixed up in the best way possible. Even dogs may stay here now not just soldiers. Anyway, it is nice and warm except that you can choke from the smoke. First of all they told us to bring in all the things we would need. We bought flour and we had our provisions brought in and we were all settled in here.

First of all they told us to bring in all the things we would need.    We bought flour and we had our provisions brought in and we were all settled in here.

data.title: The Long Winter Begins
data.description:
Then our "boss" arrived, the brigade general Kotnievitch. We all jumped in parade formation and he reviewed each of us carefully and said: "see to it that you fix yourself up because you look poorly. We will spend the winter here and then we will go back to Russia, to our old place." We were very happy to hear this news - it really refreshed each one of us.

To pass the winter here is a difficult thing. The bitter cold here is harsh. Every night we hear shooting and we don't know where it is corning from - the threat of death hangs over us.

While we are staying here we have to go on patrol for two days at a stretch and that is bad - you don't get enough rest.

The Chinese who lived here keep on returning to their homes with their wives and their children and they became our “good friends." They provide us with our needs and necessities. There is no dark flour around here for baking bread - only white. What is so bad about that? We eat white bread. The portions we get are pretty good - one pound per person. You get all the tea you want but there is no sugar and when you can get any it costs 60 kopecks a pound. Soap costs 30 kopecks a pound. A little box of shoe polish costs 15 kopecks. A sheet of paper for letter writing costs 5 kopecks. It costs about 30 kopecks to send a letter because nobody has any ink so you have to buy it. Tobacco is cheap but it is not prepared - you buy tobacco leaves.

Russian soldier’s cheap tobacco - moichorka - for which we pay 38 kopecks is 20 kopecks.

Chandza - Chinese whiskey - is cheap. It tastes like aquavit - it has a flavor and aroma and you can get drunk quickly.

In any case, the cold is killing us because the freezing temperatures are unbearable and no matter how much we heat the ovens it is still cold. We inhale a lot of smoke and when we lie down to sleep one of us remains awake to make sure that no one is overcome by smoke during the night. It is sometimes difficult to get up in the morning and you have to wait for the medic to bandage your head. Some soldiers were overcome by smoke more than once. But what can you do? You can't sleep in the street.

data.title: Settling In
data.description:
We were ordered to make our clothing warmer so we bought cotton batting and we sewed it into our pants. We also got fur pelts and sewed them into hats which were big enough to cover our ears. And mittens were sewn out of these pelts as well. And to cover our feet (and legs) and keep warm we used whatever we could find. When you are out on patrol for two hours in this climate the cold becomes unbearable. And then you sit and drink tea.

Wealthy Chinese come here and play cards with our battalion commander all night.He wins a lot of money and they say: "Captain shanza." To the Chinese an officer of any rank is a "captain" - he may be a general or a lieutenant - it is all the same.

We are learning to speak Chinese. We are getting used to them and to bargaining with them. They bring us Chinese sugar which is either black or yellow. It "only" takes a half pound of sugar to sweeten a cup of tea and even then it is not very sweet.

Eggs are very cheap - 1 kopeck an egg. Fish is cheap - 11 kopecks a pound but there is no place to cook it.

data.title: Gunshots in the Night
data.description:
One night we were awakened by gun fire. We woke up in a hurry, as if we were in a blaze, jumped into our clothes and ran outside. We walked a few viorst into a burned Chinese village.

The Chinese ran towards us and fell on their knees begging us to save them. They had been attacked by Fanfaz i.e. Chinese bandits, who beat and robbed them, set the village on fire and escaped. They begged us to protect them from the bandits.

The Fanfaz are bandits who although Chinese rob and kill their own people. We looked for them in the forest and found all five of them. They were armed and on horseback We immediately “invited" them into our fort. We turned them over to the Cossacks who took them to Charbin where they will receive their due.

data.title: The End of a Fanfaz Leader
data.description:
One time the village elder came running. He asked our battalion commander to give him a sword and a few soldiers because he caught the leader of the Fanfaz who they had been searching for a long time and he wanted to kill the bandit.

My commandant didn’t need to be begged. He immediately ordered 20 armed soldiers to accompany the man and bring the prisoner back alive.

It didn't take long for them to bring the “guest." A Chinese policeman, a general and a Chinese colonel came along as well. They took the accused, stripped him naked, tied his hands behind his back and pushed him to his knees. A Chinese man dressed in red with the sword in his hand and the elder of the village said a few words to the accused and beheaded him.

His head was hung on a pole in the middle of the village and the rest of the body was thrown away.

data.description:

Now a new bit of news arrived: the 4th battalion had a disastrous fire. Twenty soldiers lost all their belongings, including their rifles. When their battalion commander found out what a disaster had befallen his soldiers he came running. He saw his soldiers standing stark naked in the street in this bitter cold and he almost cried. He will be accountable for all these things and for the rifles as well. He is a lost man.

He immediately sent a telegram to the regiment commander and they sent new clothing for the soldiers and rifles. On the third day a commission of inquiry was set up and each soldier was awarded 12 rubles for his lost property although their stuff wasn't worth 12 goulden.

data.title: The Loot in the Chanzda Factory
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: San Dzian

While all this was going on we were informed that Fanfaz bandits were seen roaming the area. Half a battalion soldiers and ten Cossacks went out looking for them. We marched 20 viorst (21) looking for them but couldn't find a trace.

However, while looking for them we walked into a chandza factory (gin mill) and found swords, rifles and bayonets. We looked some more and found a box of gold in the attic. Our officers wouldn't allow us to touch it. Nevertheless, we took all this stuff and sent it to Charbin and there they will decide what to do with all that.

Then came the Chinese and brought presents for our battalion commander because he helped them get rid of all the Fanfaz thieves in one day. The Chinese brought our officers a gift of 3 Russian flags all made of silk. The presentation of these flags was accompanied by a colorful parade of jangling chains, Chinese music and the setting off of Chinese fireworks.

The soldiers received 2 rubles each for whiskey and they wanted us to dance. We received whiskey anyway in addition to the money.

data.title: "Time just passes by."
data.description:

We remain stationed here and time just passes by. We are suffering all kinds of miseries which I am not able to describe; miseries of a serious nature as well as minor irritations (in addition to the big ones). We are stationed near a river and that seems to be the source of this bitter cold. There is no place to do your laundry. We wash our laundry in the river and it seems that our hands are about to freeze and fall off whenever we put our hands into this cold water.

data.title: An Attack on the Bayansasa Cossacks
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: San Dzian

We were told that at night while the Cossacks were sleeping, about 1000 Chinese attacked the city. Suddenly the Cossacks heard shooting and before they even had a chance to get dressed 4 of them were already dead. The others managed to flee to Fan Dziah where the division commander was stationed and they told him what had happened.

Our two battalions were immediately sent out on horseback. When we arrived in Beynu Sasa not even a living dog was to be found there and four Cossacks were lying dead on the ground. The Chinese took with them their horses and their swords, their rifles and everything they could put their hands on.

In Beynu Sasa lived a Chinese general whose son was killed by these Chinese soldiers.

They wanted to kill him too but he managed to ransom his life for 400 rubles. This kind of business goes on here all the time and you can never get to the bottom of things.

That's how the business with the Fanfaz goes - one minute they are soldiers in battle with you and the next minute you don't recognize them. That's how they behave in the toughest battle: when things don't go their way they throw away their uniforms and their weapons and suddenly they appear as peasants with shovels in their hands: "I am only a laborer."

data.title: Leaving Fin Dziah "...just like horses."
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: unknown

In the morning we left Fin Dziah. We still had to march 790 viorst on foot. The first day we had to march 30 viorst. We left at 5 o'clock in the morning, yawning and barely able to stay on our feet.

The reason for our misery is the weight we have to carry - just like horses. We have to carry our heavy shine (soldier's overcoat) covered with a fur pelt, a rucksack containing our underwear, water canteen, ammunition and all kinds of small items. It is a heavy burden and on top of all the other items already mentioned you have to carry your rifle. You drag everything with all your strength - you could say: with your life - and you curse the day you were born.

About 5 o'clock in the afternoon we entered a Chinese chandza factory (or: gin mill). Here we will have to spend the night. We enter the building, we throw down our heavy packs which are pressing on us and are killing us. Suddenly things seemed a lot better. Now we begin to feel the pains. One soldier yells. "My hand!" Another can't stand up on his feet.

After we rest up a bit we forget some of our troubles. We walk outside to look around and to see where we are. We see chickens, ducks and geese running around. When we go to buy this poultry the fun begins. For every one who pays cash nine simply steal.

Some soldiers quickly build a fire and we start cooking. One soldier is eating. Another is cooking and another is getting himself thoroughly drunk so that he doesn't know what's going on around him and he falls asleep. We rested up and when we reminded ourselves that tomorrow we must continue the march - the thought made our hair stand on end.

First we lay down on the bare ground to go to sleep, then we got some straw to put under ourselves and we slept through the night quite comfortably because we were dead tired.

Notes:

*shinel=coat

**790 viorst=520 miles

*** 30 viorst=20 miles

data.title: Seven days of bitter cold
data.description:
We are awakened at 5 o'clock in the morning, are served a meal and we continue on our way. It was agreed upon that after one hour we will rest because the going (walking) was tough. After three hours march, it was agreed we will stop for a whole hour.

A whole to-do started about building a fire in order to warm up. Since everybody had his own cook-set everybody rushed to find water to boil tea. We stacked up our rifles, we built up a fire, and we drank tea and ate hardtack biscuits. During this one hour we ate, we drank, we boiled tea, we warmed ourselves around the fire and we answered natures call. Then we were on our way.

And thus we fought the bitter cold and suffered for seven days. Every night we slept in a different place.

The frost is fierce - it bums your nostrils. Your breath turns to steam which freezes and burns your eyes shut so that you can barely see where you are going. This is how we march all day long - one falls and another marches on.

Some soldiers are just too exhausted to continue and they are put in rickshaws which are following us. We would gladly pay the 75 kopecks a day for carrying our things but these are no more rickshaws to be had. In addition to all our other problems we are responsible for transporting our artillery. When we come to a hill the horses refuse to proceed because they are slipping on the ice. Now we have to drag the horses and the cannons up the hills ourselves. We also had an incident when we had to sit and wait all night. The horses refused to budge - by any means because it was dark and slippery.

data.title: Arrival in Nikolsk
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Nikolsk Нико́льск, Уссури́йск

On Jan. 7 we arrived in Nikolsk. We disembarked from the train and a new world greeted us. We can now see white faces for up to now we have only seen the dark­ skinned Chinese. Many of us lifted our hands to the Living God that He helped us in our needs and troubles without end and protected us from all evil. And we prayed for continued help that we should not have to face again the evil, dark-as-the-devil Chinese with their long braids.

We arrive at the railroad station in Nikolsk as the music is playing. We disembark from the train. We were happy to be finished with Manchuria where we could have gotten killed. We were delighted to see a Russian city again in front of us. Then as we look around we see people as dark-faced as the Chinese. They are dressed from head to toe in white and are wearing fedora style hats. At first we thought that they were ghosts, but ghosts don't wear fedoras. We asked around what kind of animal this was and we were told that these were Koreans.

Nikolsk is a large Russian city. Here you find people of various nationalities. Russians, Poles, Chinese and Koreans. You even find a couple of Jews here and the dark-faced Japanese who are all dressed in European clothes.

We are being housed in barracks and we're resting up after this difficult journey.

On the 1st of February general Lenievitch arrived. He is well-known as the conqueror of the capital city of Peking.

He continued his speech announcing that the Czar was rewarding us for our service by giving each soldier one silver ruble and 3 pounds of tobacco. He wished us all a healthy, safe return.

As we shouted: "Hurrah! Hurrah!" he bowed while the band played joyously. The review ended and we returned to our barracks.

data.description:

The next day we were happy. We were given our silver rubles and the tobacco. We were also given vodka and we drank to the health of the Czar.

We put ourselves to work preparing for the journey.

Each soldier was issued linen-cloth to sew his own shirt and pant. The cloth had been cut out but not stitched together. We were issued additional warm weather items: a high weight cap, a pair of sandals and two towels. We were preparing to travel on the Red Sea (and other places) where it is very hot and we could not wear our winter clothing any more.

Now started a great to do about the new clothing. There weren't enough tailors around. Time was short. Therefore we had to sew our own uniforms.

We made many comical mistakes. In the place where the neck should have been someone sewed in a sleeve. We ripped more than we sewed. And the pants - someone sewed both trouser legs together and the length - the trousers didn't even reach the knees.

The project was completed in a few days. We put on our new clothing. We stood for inspection and the battalion commander said that we looked like corpses.

He gave a speech: "within a few days we will ship out of here. Be sure to take care of everything that it should be clean" and he left.

data.title: Life in Nikolsk
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Nikolsk Нико́льск, Уссури́йск

While we are stationed in Nikolsk we go into town every day. We observe the Chinese and their customs. They wear double pairs of pants held up by suspenders and round brimmed hats. Boots are not seen here, only linen sandals.

It seems that their women do nothing but sit and eat. As she totters on her tiny feet she waddles like a hen. She can't go very far and wears high heeled shoes. They carry their babies strapped on their backs.

When a person dies, he is placed in a coffin. The coffin is stood upright under the window of his house. Chinese do not put people in prisons. If a person is found guilty of a crime, he is beheaded.

People here do not eat with knives and forks. Most of them eat with their hands. Those with good manners eat with two sticks which appear like a fork. They are allowed to eat the meat of horses and dogs but not pigs.

They believe in idols. They worship statues in the shapes of dogs, pigs and other such animals. They sleep naked as the day they were born. They don't have window panes. They use oiled paper instead. They don’t eat bread but what appears to be scallion pancakes friend in oil. For lighting they used oil lamps.

That's how they live in Manchuria. There is much more to write but the rest I will remember myself.

As a remembrance of China I allowed myself to be photographed with a Chinese person. We’re sitting here but we really can’t believe that we are leaving (for home).

data.title: Part II The Journey from Manchuria Back to Zhmerinke in Russia.
data.description:
Modern Name/Spelling: Владивосто́к

Now I am going to describe the trip back from Manchuria to Russia by sea. We arrive at the port of Vladivostok and prepare to board the vessel that will take us back to Zhmerinke, Russia.

For six months prior we have seen few people other than our fellow soldiers. Now we see lots of people of various colors and races. We look at the people and they are as curious as we are and stare back at us.

The mood is festive and shared by all. An army band is present and plays festive marching tunes as we board the boat. The crowd on shore cheers us on and we shout in excitement. "Hurrah. Hurrah! Goodbye Manchuria, goodbye, and hurrah for Russia and Zhmerinka -- our home base."

The boat is very big. We stay on the upper deck to watch the boat depart as the crowd on shore tosses their hats in the air. Some wave their handkerchiefs in a final good-bye to us. The boat's horns blast away and, slowly but surely, we depart for the open sea.

The date is March 5th. 1901, and I am sure happy that we are leaving Vladivostok. Our presence in Manchuria should now be thought of as a bad dream and the reality is the happiness of sailing back home, even though a very long and arduous trip is ahead of us.

There are lots of people on the boat in addition to us. There are also civilian travelers and among the military there's also General Lenevitz.

We are now below deck and we each get a bed and a straw mattress. For us it is a very happy experience. We haven't slept in such luxury for months. The boat is very clean and there are electric lights all over. We feel extremely delighted by our surroundings - it's like being in God's Heaven!

All we see now as we sail on is sky and water. At first, the sea is very calm and all are on deck enjoying the pleasant weather. Little did we know that we were only in the Bay of Vladivostok and not quite in the open sea. We were soon ready for a rude awakening. Just after we had our supper, the boat suddenly started to wobble from side to side and we were in for it. Everybody started to feel seasick. Many brought up everything they ate and some suffered other unpleasant symptoms such as headache and nausea. Some of us are so sick that we drop wherever we are.

Unable to find our beds as the motion of the ship is unsteady at best. I too, am very sick. I have the sensation that my guts are all twisted and that I'll never survive this ordeal. We are each given lemon to chew on and that seems to alleviate our sea sickness somewhat. Some complain about their teeth and gums as a result of the lemon tartness but it is still better than being sick.

We are now below deck and we each get a bed and a straw mattress.    For us it is a very happy experience. We haven't slept in such luxury for months. The boat is very clean and there are electric lights all over. We feel extremely delighted by our surroundings - it's like being in God's Heaven!

data.title: "...we enter the port city of Nagasaki."
data.description:
After sailing for three days we arrive at an island in the Sea of Japan. On the 9th of March at 5:00 in the afternoon, we enter the port city of Nagasaki. After the ship has docked at the pier a Japanese inspection crew boards us. They are to inspect both cargo and passengers. As it turns out, it's a mere formality and they depart as soon as they arrived. There are ships from many countries anchored at the Port of Nagasaki; we see flags from various nations - American. English. French and Japanese.

Suddenly, a flotilla of small boats approaches our vessel. They are packed full of goods for sale; we can buy anything imaginable. All kinds of food stuff, baked goods, citrus fruit, cigarettes and soft drinks. They also have gold and silver jewelry. The desire to purchase something is very strong but most of us have little or no money, so we have to satisfy ourselves with just enjoying the sight. Some passengers got into a fist fight with the vendors after not being able to pay for their purchase. One person got beat up to serve as an example for others, not to take merchandise for which he was not able to pay. The cheapest of all goods was tea 25 to 30 kopeks a pound where as in Russia, it would cost 2 or even 3 Rubles.

data.description:
We sail on and see nothing but endless seas, blue sky and a hot sun. Occasionally, we pass another boat or small island, and then again, the same monotony.

The heat becomes almost unbearable. Our new clothing is getting wet and heavy, as we sweat profusely. Had it not been for our sense of feeling ashamed, we would have walked about naked!

Our boat begins to rock back and forth and from side to side. A motion disagreeable to most of us and we begin another bout with sea sickness. We are trying to stay on deck since sea sickness below deck is an even worse experience. But there is little or no room for everybody, and it's impossible to find a shady spot to be protected from the punishing sun rays.

Every other day is laundry day. We have to do it ourselves and the only water we can use is salt water. We find the salt water needs more soap to make suds and that presents a problem, as well. We have to do the best we can under the circumstances and hopefully our soap supply will outlast our dirt.

These were the conditions and circumstances under which we sailed until the 20th of March, the day we finally reached Singapore.

data.title: Passover Docked in Singapore
data.description:
To our surprise, we also found some Jews, which at first made us happy. But then, to our chagrin, we realized that they didn't want to admit their Jewishness and turned away from us.

This was a real disappointment to me and some of my fellow Jews. It was Passover time and we were very happy when we saw other fellow Jews. Who could help but recognize our brethren when the distinctive kugel* on their faces was a sure giveaway?

We'll have to celebrate Passover on the boat as best as we possibly can. "Maror"** is plentiful. Our lives and fate are full of bitterness. "Saltwater”*** - there's plenty of it; we are surrounded by a salty sea. We are even able to obtain eggs, thanks to the local vendors. The only thing we can't get is "Matzos."**** Had we been able to obtain that, we could really have had a great Passover celebration. But there's no use in bemoaning our sad circumstances. We are lucky to be alive and well and we are on our way home - thank the almighty God.

Notes:

*kugel = baked casseroles or puddings, often made out of potatoes or noodles. Some Passover recipes use Matzah.

**Maror = Bitter herbs eaten as part of the Passover Seder ritual meal.

***Saltwater = Herbs, and sometimes hard-boiled eggs, are dpiped in saltwater as part of the Passover Seder ritual meal.

****Matzos = Unleavened bread as part of the Passover Seder ritual meal

data.title: Shore Leave After All
data.description:
The same day, after supper, we were told that we would be allowed to visit the city of Singapore. I was one of the first ones to report. But they wouldn't let us go on our own. Soon we found out the reason for the restriction. There were apparently desertions in the past and Fonie is afraid of future escapes.

Finally, after a lot of thinking and organizing we are allowed to march ashore in small groups, headed by officers and non-commissioned personnel.

We stroll aimlessly through the city streets and view everything with great delight. We see enormous buildings, lots of shops stocked with various goods, and a throng of people buzzing like bees. Our feet are beginning to feel sore. Finally, around midnight, we are escorted back to our ship and fall asleep right away, as we were all exhausted.

data.title: Of Showers and Songs
data.description:
Seldom do we see another boat and when we see a fish rise above the waves or a small island, we get somewhat excited. A make-shift bath house is erected on board. We can take showers twice daily. Because of the heat, we walk around without shoes or hats and the camaraderie grows among us fellow soldiers. We tell stories and jokes to one another and that helps us escape boredom. Often groups are formed according to one's nationality; Jewish, Polish, Russian, etc. But the most exciting activity is when all of us, regardless of who one might be, join together in song, singing familiar songs that remind us of our families far away, and our longing to return home soon. This kind of activity helps to raise our spirits and for a short while we forget the ills of this world.

At night our troubles begin again; we are experiencing another sea storm. We have to hold onto our beds or we'll topple out of them. In addition, the heat below deck is suffocating. We can't find much relief anywhere from these conditions but somehow, we manage to survive the night.

data.title: "...we arrive at the city of Colombo in Ceylon."
data.description:
We survived the storm though and on the 26th of March we arrive at the city of Colombo in Ceylon which is a British colony. There are many boats in the harbor and we see flags of many countries such as American, British, French, Chinese and Japanese. The people here are different as well. Some are white but many are black as soot. Their teeth though, are extremely white and shimmer like crystal.

Suddenly, our attention is drawn to a little wooden raft with about six people on it. For a penny, they'll sing a song. For some small change, they'll sing and clap hands and perform various other tricks. Some of the ship's officers decide to have some fun. They invite the performers to come on board, all the way to the upper deck.

From there, the officers toss some money into the sea and tell the poor souls to jump after it. We look at the spectacle and fear for the lives of the local performers. They're sure to get killed or drown if they jump. Is it worthwhile to risk one’s life for a few pennies? Will they jump? We wait to see what will happen. For a moment, they hesitate but then, they suddenly seem to gather strength and leap from the upper deck - about three stories high - to the bottom of the sea to retrieve the money.

We are all speechless and watch in horror over what has happened. Surely, they won’t survive.

But, after a few minutes, they all emerge safe and sound. They signal with their hands that they have accomplished their task, get back on their raft and wave goodbye to us all. We feel greatly relieved and look upon what happened as a good omen. Our boat remained in Colombo for a while longer. This time in addition to our regular supplies of coal, water and food we also get all kinds of goods to be taken to Odessa, our final destination.

Notes:

Ceylon is now Sri Lanka

data.title: Burial at Perim
data.description:
We arrived at Perim at 9 in the morning, the following day. Perim was actually a small island at the southern entrance of the Red Sea and it was a British colony. Sadly, Perim was destined to be the final resting place for the poor officer.

On a small boat, accompanied by an honor guard of riflemen, the officer's body was taken to the Perim Island. There, as we were told later, the officer was given his final rites, according to full military honor with pomp and ceremony.

None of the members of my company knew the officer nor did any of us have any particular love for an officer yet we all felt sad. We felt sad because this officer had managed to survive the war and was on his way home, and here, suddenly, he is buried in a strange land, far away from his home and family. The only thing we had to be grateful for was that he was not thrown into the water - that would have been a cruel fate - to be eaten by fish in the ocean.

Our boat did not linger much on Perim. There was the -usual loading of supplies, though with a twist this time. Our boat got a thorough cleaning on the outside. Workers toiled for a whole day to scrub off the build-up of moss and other debris. Then it was washed and hosed down neatly. This task completed and also the loading of the goods our ship was ready to resume its voyage.

Suddenly, the band (always present with us on board) erupted in a happy tune. This lifted our spirits right away. The music was always used as a morale builder. This time, it was especially appropriate, after the incident with the dead officer – our morale was quite low.

As the music was playing, we all watched the anchors being lifted and our boat slowly sailed into the open sea. This time, our destination-the city of Suez in the Red Sea.

data.description:
On a quiet morning, April 10th, we arrived at Suez city, a big port at the southern tip of the Suez Canal. It looks like the city is surrounded by water on all sides. It looked like the boat was gliding through the city street. We couldn't help but admire the beautiful buildings and the well-manicured gardens that we saw. And. as we marveled at everything before our eyes I thought it was a paradise. The people were all well and colorfully dressed. We saw Britons in their European garb and Arabs and Turks in their colorful robes. Everybody was very friendly and welcomed our arrival. Some were waving their hats in a welcoming greeting, others waved handkerchiefs. We passed by a French vessel and. as our band started to play a cheerful tune, we proceeded to holler on top of our voices: "Hurrah, hurrah!" as is customary when saluting a friendly nation.

The French and our Czar are now on friendly terms, thus the reason for the big commotion. The French vessel did not carry an orchestra with them, but the crew on board still managed to greet us warmly. In the meantime, out boat had to dock and as it turned out, we were supposed to wait for a pilot boat which would guide us through the Suez Canal to Port Said.

When the pilot boat arrived, it was already dark. But the pilot boat is equipped with electrical lights which cast a strong light upon the water for hundreds of feet ahead. Again we were stunned at this kind of a modem, wonderful achievement.

Thus our journey began through the Suez Canal. At first we go through and past the city of Suez itself. Even at night we are able to see that the city is very big, and the canal is like a street cutting through it. It was pitch dark when we were sailing through the canal. but the strong lights of the pilot boat illuminated our way beautifully - it almost looked like daylight was in front of us. The canal is very narrow and when another boat approaches from the opposite direction, one has to stop to allow room for the other to pass. That is the only way the boats can navigate their passage through the canal in both directions. It took us a whole night to sail through the canal.

data.title: Port Said
data.description:
It took us a whole night to sail through the canal and the following day, April 11th, we arrived at Port Said.

The city and the canal used to belong to France, but now belong to England. Two important people were associated with the construction of the canal, a Frenchman (Ferdinand de Leseps) and a Turk (Said Pasha - Turkish Viceroy to Egypt). A monument in their honor has been erected near the canal and their images are right there for all to see, pointing their hands toward the waterway. It took many years to build the canal and it cost “buckets of money." Before the canal's existence it would take an extra month to make the trip from Asia to Africa to the Mediterranean. Now it only takes a day and it costs 1.000 Rubles. Of course, without money, no ship is allowed through the canal.

Port Said is a big harbor and a city with an international population. British. French.

Greek, Turkish. Arabic and even Jewish people lived there. The Jewish people, though, speak Arabic or "Loshn Koidesh*" and do not speak "jargon**." Most Jews we encountered are dressed like the local populace. They are mostly merchants, and they came aboard offering goods for sale. things like hand-made rugs and jewelry. They are fluent in English. French. Russian, but not Yiddish.

We asked them if there were many Jewish people in Port Said and their answer was about 50 families who originally were exiled generations ago from the Holy Land and found refuge in Egypt.

Egypt was truly not far from the Holy Land. As we departed Port Said, somebody pointed out to us and at a distance, we could distinguish the contours of Mount Sinai where our forefathers received the Holy Torah. In addition, we could also see the location where Moses and the children of Israel crossed the Red Sea on their way to the Promised Land.

Notes:

* Loshn Koidesh = Hebrew

**Jargon = Yiddish

data.title: "The Mediterranean was supposed to be a "quiet sea..."
data.description:
On April 12th, a strong rain accompanied by strong winds hit our ship again. It was something very terrifying, and I was sure that we'd be lost forever. [PAGE 17] It's impossible to gain a secure foothold anywhere on board. The ship was tossed around like a mere toy, and people were falling over each other in a futile attempt to stay in one place.

Some were keeling over, others complained about tremendous headaches; others were just too exhausted and were suffering in silence. The Mediterranean was supposed to be a "quiet" sea but we sure were proven wrong.

data.title: "the fortified city of Konstantinopol."
data.description:
In spite of the bad weather, our ship maintained its course, and on April 13th, we reached the Dardanelles in Turkey. By then the storm abated and we crossed the narrow passageway sailing towards the fortified city of Konstantinopol*. The city is of enormous size and has very strong fortifications. They go back to the days when the Turks fought against the Russians**. Konstantinopol became an international city with military garrisons of France, Britain and even Russia, making their presence felt there.

Again, we were being swamped by local merchants who arrived with all kinds of exotic fabrics for sale, such as hand-woven rugs, colorful kerchiefs, shawls, etc. We were already saturated with this kind of merchandise, yet it was always interesting and colorful to both watch and participate in the barter. We were at the time, running out of soap, especially the kind which we used for laundry. We were hoping that we'd be able to get it from the local merchants. We needed to do our last load of laundry before arriving in Russia. So, for the last time, the boat took on provisions, as we were about to enter the home waters of the Black Sea - on our way to our final destination - Odessa.

As rumor had it, though, we were to sail to Feodosiya instead of Odessa, our original destination. But, what difference does it make to us soldiers, as long as we were finally back in our homeland? At last, the end to this boat trip.

Notes:

*Konstantinopol is now Instanbul

**During the Crimean War 1863-1866

data.title: A burial at sea
data.description:
In the meantime, one of the soldiers on board suddenly died. Unlike the officer before him, who was given almost royal burial, the soldier's body was going to be disposed of forthwith. Soldiers were a "dime a dozen", and the procedure for burial at sea was as follows: The body is bound with ropes to an iron rod, which, in turn, is put in a canvas bag and tucked in tightly. Then the bag is sewn tightly. The ceremony is short and lasts only a few moments. Only a brief prayer is said. The body then glides off a wooden plank into the sea and the poor soul is allowed to "learn how to swim." However, he won't "swim" very long; soon the body will be attacked by sharks, who sniff the dead body out and proceed to have a royal feast. The scene was so gruesome and inhumane that most of us turned away, sickened, unable to witness the spectacle.

This was certainly done differently than the officer's burial. Most of us felt more compassion for the poor soldier with whom we could identify than for the officer.
